member.summary: Standard tag property for the control.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.DayOrientedScheduleView.TimeDisplayFormat
member.summary: Determines how times are displayed: 0 = Time12Hour (h:mm AM/PM) 1 = Time24Hour (hh:mm) 2 = Clock 3 = None (Appointment's start time not displayed) 4 = UseSystemSetting (Builds the display string based on the current culture's LongDatePattern)

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.DayOrientedScheduleView.ToolTips
member.summary: Determines whether tooltips are displayed for appointments and/or notes. Note that the TipStyleActivity enumerated constants are bitflags so that different combinations of activities can be more easily supported (especially if we add toolips for holidays at a later time) 0 = None (Tooltips are not displayed for appointments or notes) 1 = Appointments (Tooltips are displayed for appointments) 2 = Notes (Tooltips are displayed for notes) -1 = All (Tooltips are displayed for both appointments and notes)

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.DayOrientedScheduleView.WeekendDisplayFormat
member.summary: Determines how weekend days are displayed: 0 = Compressed (Sat. and Sun. are displayed in one column, split horizontally) 1 = Full

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.DayOrientedScheduleView.YearDisplayFormat
member.summary: Determines how the year portion of the date is displayed in the DayUIElements: 0 = FirstDayOfYear (The year is only displayed for January 1st) 1 = FirstDayOfMonth (The year is displayed for the first day of every month) 2 = Never (The year is never displayed) Note This property works in conjunction with the DayDisplayFormat property. When DayDisplayFormat = Auto, the year is displayed in 4-digit format where space permits, and in 2-digit format otherwise. When DayDisplayFormat = Full, the year is always displayed in 4-digit format; when DayDisplayFormat = Medium, in 2-digit format, and it is not shown at all when DayDisplayFormat = Short

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.IUIHierarchyNodeList.Remove(Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.IUIHierarchyNode)
member.summary: Removes the first occurrence of an IUIHierarchyNode within the list.
member.param: The node being removed from the list.

remarks.p: The IUIHierarchyNodeList is comprised of contiguous elements causing the IUIHierarchyNode instances following the removed node to move up one space filling-in the vacancy. Applications retaining indexes to nodes later in the list must refresh (or invalidate) these indexes following one or more removal operations.

Implementations of that require the Remove method to function based on a node's value equivalency must override Equals and GetHashCode when their class implements IUIHierarchyNode, otherwise the node must be reference identical to an IUIHierarchyNode within the list for it to be removed.
When node cannot be located within the list, this method has no effect.

member.exception: Thrown when either of the or properties return True.

Applications retaining indexes to nodes later in the list must refresh (or invalidate) these indexes following one or more removal operations.

member.exception: Thrown when the index is outside of the boundaries of nodes contained within the list.

member.summary: Removes the first occurrence of an IUIHierarchyNode within the list.
member.param: The node being removed from the list.

remarks.p: The IUIHierarchyNodeList is comprised of contiguous elements causing the IUIHierarchyNode instances following the removed node to move up one space filling-in the vacancy. Applications retaining indexes to nodes later in the list must refresh (or invalidate) these indexes following one or more removal operations.

Implementations of that require the Remove method to function based on a node's value equivalency must override Equals and GetHashCode when their class implements IUIHierarchyNode, otherwise the node must be reference identical to an IUIHierarchyNode within the list for it to be removed.
When node cannot be located within the list, this method has no effect.

member.exception: Thrown when either of the IsReadOnly or IsFixedSize properties return True.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement
member.summary: Abstraction of a rectangular UI element within the scene graph.

remarks.p: UI elements are abstractions of the control surfaces comprising a web element.

Each such control surfaces may have a certain style of appearance, it may offer a certain degree of user interactivity through receiving focus and/or handling client-side events, and it may expose other appearance-impacting properties.
They may be related to a object that is meaningful in the context of more specialized UIElement subclasses.

Every UI element also has the specialized knowledge of how to render itself, frequently driven by the settings of its properties and the its been associated with. This target is meaningful within the context of more specialized UIElement subclasses. These subclasses may further override the method to customize the appearance or build off of a template established by its base classes.

UI elements are maintained in a hierarchical tree structure starting with the most expansive rectangular region at the root of this tree, and subsequent UI elements in progressively deeper child collections that cover decreasingly-sized regions. When rendered this tree (the scene graph) gets flattened such that deeper children within this tree take precedence over and cover regions of their parents.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an empty instance of UIElement that has no corresponding target object that it renders.

remarks.p: By default, all UIElement instances are initially created with their state set to True. If an application requires that the UIElement be disabled, it should set that after the hierarchical scene graph has been constructed. This allows the setting to cascade across all child UIElement instances that compose this one.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.#ctor(System.Object,Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.IUIHierarchyNode@)
member.summary: Creates an instance of UIElement around an underlying object. The UIElement represents the look and feel of this object as it will be rendered.
member.param: An underlying object that may have additional properties on it that determine how it should be rendered. Support for specific types of target objects are added by more specialized subclasses of UIElement.
An IUIHierarchyNode that is returned to the caller which wraps the newly constructed UIElement. Inheritors should attach this to the tree-structured scene graph they become a part of.

remarks.p: By default, all UIElement instances are initially created with their state set to True. If an application requires that the UIElement be disabled, it should set that after the hierarchical scene graph has been constructed. This allows the setting to cascade across all child UIElement instances that compose this one.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.InitializeView(System.Web.UI.Control)
member.summary: This method supports the internal Infragistics infrastructure, and is not intended for application use.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.Render(System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter)
member.summary: Renders the current UIElement to the specified HtmlTextWriter instance.
member.param: An HtmlTextWriter instance into which markup will be deposited as this UIElement instance, and the child UIElement instances composing it render themselves.

remarks.p: By default, this Render method doesn't emit any markup. It only iterates through its collection of child UIElement instances within the scene graph and asks them to render their markup, if any.

Inheritors wishing for their Render method to produce markup must override this method and furnish their own implementation to produce the markup that their UIElement instance adds to the composition. For child UIElement instances to properly receive the command to render themselves, the overridden method MUST call the base class' Render method, or dispatch calls to the Render methods of its children on its own.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.ShouldRenderChild(Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement)
member.summary: Determines whether a particular child UIElement should have Render called upon it by the base class' implementation of Render.
member.param: The child UIElement.
member.returns: This method always returns True when child is not null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET); inheritors may override this implementation when providing custom logic to filter out certain child UIElements from being rendered by returning False when such conditions are met.

remarks.p: Inheritors should call the base implementation, and logically-AND the result of that call with the boolean result of their own custom processing. This ensures that a NullReferenceException doesn't occur because the base class' check of whether this child UIElement was null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) was overridden.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.PostRenderChild(System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter,Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement)
member.summary: Notifies a parent UIElement following the rendering of one of its children.
member.param: The sink into which to deposit additional markup as may be required.
The child UIElement that has just rendered.

remarks.p: The base class implementation of this method does nothing. Inheritors may override this method to track information about the progress of the rendering, or follow the rendering of certain children with special rendering by the parent.

An example of when overriding PostRenderChild is necessary is if a parent containing this UIElement must render markup after every other child UIElement. In this example, the implementation provided by the subclass would need to maintain a counter, incrementing it as it receives each notification. On every second notice, the implementation could trigger special rendering code in the base class to produce this markup.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.Depth
member.summary: Calculates the depth of the current UIElement within the scene graph.

value.p: The depth, or distance from the root UIElement containing everything within the scene, of this UIElement instance when it is part of the scene graph.
When the current instance is detached from a scene graph, this property returns -1.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.Enabled
member.summary: Indicates whether this UIElement is enabled or disabled.
member.value: True when the current UIElement is enabled, otherwise False when it has been disabled.

remarks.p: Setting the Enabled property on a UIElement that is composed of many child UIElements also cascades down and enables/disables the children for a consistent look-and-feel.

An enabled UIElement generally has a default or non-disabled style applied to it, and if it supports user interactivity then it will do so. Conversely, a disabled UIElement will have a disabled style applied and does not expose user interactivity.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.Implementation
member.summary: Retrieves a reference to the type factories that conceal an interface's actual implementing class.
member.value: A reference to the UIElement.UIElementImplementation which contains methods for getting an implementation to one of the interfaces needed by a UIElement or its subclasses.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Render.UIElement.Key
member.summary: Identifies the current UIElement instance with a user-supplied name.
member.value: The name by which this user interface element is known during render-time, if one has been assigned. Otherwise the property may refer to null (or Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) when no key was assigned.

remarks.p: Some inheritors may employ the Key property as a tag that facilitates identifying or categorizing an instance of UIElement without requiring run-time type identifications (RTTI) in overrides of protected methods like and .

No checks are performed as to whether the key assigned is unique within the hierarchical scene graph, or any fragment thereof. It is the application's responsibility to handle the ramifications of having duplicate keys.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.DayHeadingUIElement.Reset
member.summary: Restores the default property settings to this UIElement as if it had just been initialized.

remarks.p: If a date format string has been explicitly set using the property, then re-establishing the default date format string behavior requires an application to call this Reset method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.DayHeadingUIElement.Format
member.summary: Format string specifying the appearance of the month and/or day within the caption of this day heading.

remarks.p: The formatting of the day caption defaults to display a month and day number on the first day of a month that is visible to the end user, and the day number on all other days. Developers may supercede this default setting with their own custom date format specifier (see the .NET Framework SDK for more information on how to specify the formatting of dates).

After specifying a format specifier for the date on this UIElement, it will not be possible to reassign a format string that represents the default appearance. Other properties on this class like have different behavior when the default setting for the Format is applied. Therefore, properly restoring the Format to its initial state that respects other date-related settings on the class requires that the Developer call the method directly.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.DayHeadingUIElement.IsMonthAbbreviated
member.summary: Indicates whether the month name appearing in the caption is abbreviated or fully spelled out.
member.value: True when the month appears abbreviated (this is the default), otherwise False when the month should be spelled out fully (space permitting).

remarks.p: Setting this property may not affect the appearance of the date when an explicit has been specified. The property works by changing a custom date format string that identifies the month as either 'MMM' or 'MMMM'. Built-in (most commonly identified by their being one character) date format strings that rely on the short or long date patterns specified in Regional Settings are unaffected by the value assigned to IsMonthAbbreviated.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView
member.summary: The WebMonthView element is a day-oriented view on WebSchedule presenting a calendar month of information at a time to the end user.

remarks.p: The WebMonthView exposes a broad variety of customizable styles affecting its appearance. These styles control the appearance of the days, day headings and day of week headings in the current month, the leading and trailing days of neighboring months that may be visible (typically shown with a 'grayed' out look) within the month view, and the appearance of months every other (alternating) month from the active month.

Initialize the WebMonthView to collaborate with other WebSchedule views on the same Page by setting its ScheduleInfo property to a common instance of the scheduling information element also on the Page that is shared with these other views. Alternately, each WebSchedule view may operate independently based on a default instance it initializes its ScheduleInfo property to, and which developers may customize by altering the ScheduleInfo through an instance of the WebMonthView element.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a default instance of the WebMonthView.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.CreateSubObject(System.String)
member.summary: Creates sub-objects.
member.param: The string identifier for the property.
member.returns: An IStateManager implementation for the property.

remarks.p: A sub-object is an expandable or "compound" property responsible for its own state management (cf, viewstate) and must implement IStateManager. All sub-objects on the WebMonthView are Styles.

The WebControlBase class calls the override of this method when required, in reaction to calls to SetSubObject and GetSubObject. It should not be necessary for inheritors to ever invoke this method directly.

Inheritors adding additional properties that meet the definition of a sub-object should override this method if they wish to take advantage of the WebControlBase support for viewstate management. Subclasses are free to provide state management through alternative means for properties they add, as they see fit. If this method is overridden, inheritors must call the base implementation when an id is unrecognized.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.OnRaisePostBackEvent(System.String)
member.summary: Triggers server-side events and behaviors on the WebMonthView element.
member.param: Command information passed from the call the client-side script makes through fireServerEvent. This text has no relationship to the similarly-named System.EventArgs class.

remarks.p: This method gets invoked by the framework and is responsible for handling server-side events. Inheritors should not override this method to intercept server-side events before they are handled by the base class. Undefined behavior may result from interference in the event processing of the framework.
Consequently, developers that want to receive notification of an event should subscribe an event handler to the server-side events formally exposed by WebMonthView.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.CreateRenderer
member.summary: Creates a SmartRenderer of the appropriate type for the WebMonthView.
member.returns: An instance of WebMonthViewRenderer providing the rendering services required by the WebMonthView.

remarks.p: The SmartWebControl framework calls this factory method before it begins using the SmartRenderer subclass for this web element. Inheritors with their own custom SmartRenderer must override this method to see it used.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.OnPreRender(System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Performs pre-render processing.
member.param: Event arguments passed-in by the ASP.NET Framework during the PreRender stage of the page lifecycle.

remarks.p: Inheritors overriding this method must call the base class implementation. Failure to call the base implementation can lead to Javascript errors resulting from omitting <include> blocks, a loss of styling from the element, and other undesirable behavior.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.RenderContents(System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter)
member.summary: Renders contents to the supplied HtmlTextWriter.
member.param: An HtmlTextWriter sink to which output is being directed.

remarks.p: The contents associated with the WebMonthView and rendered by this method include fields to hold postback data from the client, and initialization Javascript to start-up the WebMonthView's client-side object model (CSOM) following the HTML markup comprising the element. RenderContents delegates responsibility for rendering HTML markup to the associated SmartRenderer created by .
Inheritors overriding this method must remember to call the base class implementation of the method before conducting most additional processing.

Post-processing of the rendered content can be accomplished if inheritors intercept what gets written to writer. This involves passing their own HtmlTextWriter wrapping some sort of buffered output sink, for example a StringWriter. When intercepting rendered content in this manner, it becomes the responsibility of the overriding method to ensure necessary content gets forwarded to the original HtmlTextWriter supplied by ASP.NET.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.IsAlternateMonth(System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates whether the given month is an alternate month or a non-alternate month relative to the active month. The active month (the month containing the active day) is always considered non-alternate.
member.param: The month number between 1 and 12.
member.returns: True if month is an alternate month relative to the active month; otherwise False.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.ScrollMonthIntoView(System.Int32)
member.summary: Scrolls the WebMonthView element to present the entire month specified within the currently displayed calendar year.
member.param: The number of the month (1 to 12) within the currently displayed calendar year.

remarks.p: Developers can call ScrollMonthIntoView to present the end user with the specified month. This overload of ScrollMonthIntoView remains in the currently displayed calendar year, to change the view to present a month outside of the currently displayed calendar year call instead.
This method performs no operation if the month specified is already being shown to the end user.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.ScrollMonthIntoView(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Scrolls the WebMonthView element to present the entire month requested from the specified calendar year.
member.param: The number of the month (1 to 12) within year that shall be displayed.
The calendar year number in which month falls.

remarks.p: Developers can call ScrollMonthIntoView to present the end user with a view of the specified month and year.

Calling this method may require loading substantial amounts of data, if the specified month and year are not near the ActiveDay. When browsing dates in the distant past or future, it is advisable for an application to associate a separate instance of the element with the WebMonthView, and set its ActiveDay in the desired time period. The WebMonthView will no longer coordinate with WebSchedule elements associated with its old WebScheduleInfo, but this allows it to maintain a much smaller, local cache of data focused within the far past or future time period.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebMonthView.ControlPrefix

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Activity
member.summary: Represents an Activity for a specific date and time.

remarks.p: An Activity object maintains information regarding a event or task for a particular date and time. The start and end of the Activity are stored in the or respectively. To change the start of the Activity without changing the duration, use the method.

The property may be used to indicate that an Activity occurs on a day or range of days but is not restricted to a particular time within those days. By default, Activities are rendered differently than non-AllDayEvent Activities. The appearance of all AllDayEvent type Activities can be adjusted by changing the . The can be used to change the style for all Activities. The style of an Activity can also be controlled on an individual basis by adjusting its

A new Activity, can be created by either creating a new instance of an and adding it to the collection or using the method of the collection. An Activity can also be created using the . To display the AppointmentDialog for a new Activity, use the . The overload may be used to display the Activity information for an existing Activity.
An Activity can have a associated with it. When the is reached, the will be displayed if enabled.

remarks.p: The following code will increase an Activity by one hour.

WebScheduleInfo1.Activities(0).OffsetStartTime(System.TimeSpan.FromHours(1))
ultraScheduleInfo1.Activities[0].OffsetStartTime(System.TimeSpan.FromHours(1));

member.summary: Gets/sets the object that describes the recurrence pattern that determines the frequency at which individual occurrences occur.

remarks.p: Only objects that are the of an will return a non-null value from this property; 'standalone' appointments and variances (members of a recurrence that have been modified) both return null from this property.

Note: Attempting to set the Recurrence property of an Appointment that is a member of an existing object’s collection will result in an exception being thrown. Similarly, assigning an object that is already assigned to some other object’s Recurrence property results in an exception being thrown. Also note that setting the or property of an whose Recurrence property is set will result in an exception being thrown.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Appointment
member.summary: Represents an appointment activity for a specific date and time.

remarks.p: An Appointment object maintains information regarding a task for a particular date and time. The start and end of the appointment are stored in the or respectively. The Duration property is equivalent to the EndDateTime minus the StartDateTime. The Duration property is the value that is normally saved to the DataProvider. To change the start of the appointment without changing the duration, use the method.

The property may be used to indicate that an Appointment occurs on a day or range of days but is not restricted to a particular time within those days. By default, appointments are rendered differently than non-AllDayEvent appointments. The appearance of all AllDayEvent type appointments can be adjusted by changing the . The can be used to change the appearance for all appointments. The appearance of an appointment can also be controlled on an individual basis by adjusting its

A new Appointment, can be created by either creating a new instance of an and adding it to the collection or using the method of the collection. An appointment can also be created using the . To display the AppointmentDialog for a new appointment, use the . The overload may be used to display the appointment information for an existing Appointment.
An Appointment can have a and associated with it. When the is reached, the will be displayed and the will be invoked as long as each is enabled.

summary.p: The PropChangeInfo structure contains the context information for a state change. It is passed into the SubObjectPropChanged event.

It also allows us to chain relavent context information about a property change so the a listener can get information as granular as it wants to determine what it should do when an object's state changes.

member.returns: Returns a description of the property change including the entire trigger chain

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.PropChangeInfo.FindTrigger(System.Object)
member.summary: Searches for a specific PropChangeInfo up the trigger chain based on the specified source object. Passing in null will return the root trigger element.
member.param: Source object to locate.
member.returns: The propChangeinfo trigger associated with the source or null if the specified source was not in the trigger chain.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.PropChangeInfo.Trigger
member.summary: The trigger property returns an interface if this change was triggered by a change notification from another object. Otherwise, it returns null.

remarks.p: There may be several of these state changes forming a chain. For example, if a Cell's Appearance's backcolor property changes, the Appearance object will fire an event notifying any of its listeners, in this case the Cell object, that a state change has occurred (passing null for the trigger and the propId relating to BackColor).

When the Cell gets the state change notification it will do whatever it needs to do and will forward the Appearance's PropChangeInfo as the trigger and the propId idntifying the Appearance property to notify all of its listeners, in this case perhaps the corresponding row.
Then the row will do the same (using the propId identifying its Cell property). This process will continue until the main object is reached or there are no listeners.
The advantage of this approach is that we have created efficient notification infrastructure that can supply detailed context information (as granular as the listener may want) with little overhead.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.Id
member.summary: Gets a globally unique identifier that identifies this instance. Used for deserialization purposes.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.OccurrenceDuration
member.summary: Gets/sets the duration of each occurrence in the recurrence.

remarks.p: Note: If the OccurrenceDuration property is set such that it would cause occurrences to overlap, an exception is thrown.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.OccurrenceStartTime
member.summary: Gets/sets the starting time for each "non-variance" occurrence in the recurrence.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.PatternDayOfMonth
member.summary: Gets/sets the number of the day in its respective month on which each occurrence will occur. Applicable only when the property is set to 'Monthly' or 'Yearly'.

remarks.p: Note: If the PatternDayOfMonth property is set to a value that exceeds the number of days in any of the months that the recurrence spans, the occurrence for those months will fall on the last day of that month.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.PatternDaysOfWeek
member.summary: Gets/sets the day(s) of the week on which each occurrence occurs.

remarks.p: Note: The value of the PatternDaysOfWeek property is expressed as bitflags, so that multiple days can be represented by the property.
When the property is set to 'Daily', the PatternDaysOfWeek property can only be set to 'All' or 'AllWeekdays'; setting the property to any other value will result in an exception being thrown.
When the property is set to 'Weekly', the PatternDaysOfWeek property cannot be set to 'None'; doing so will result in an exception being thrown.
When the property is set to 'Monthly' or 'Yearly', the PatternDaysOfWeek property is not applicable.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.PatternFrequency
member.summary: Gets/sets the frequency at which the recurrence occurs, i.e., whether it occurs daily, weekly, monthly or yearly.

remarks.p: Note: Since certain values are not valid for the property when PatternFrequency is set to 'Daily' or 'Weekly', the value of the property may be changed when PatternFrequency is set to 'Daily' or 'Weekly'.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.PatternInterval
member.summary: Gets/sets the interval between occurrences of the recurrence.

remarks.p: The PatternInterval property works in conjunction with the property to determine the cycle of the recurrence. For example, if the PatternFrequency is set to 'Daily', and the PatternInterval is set to 2, the recurrence occurs every other day.
Note: The PatternInterval property is not applicable when the property is set to 'Yearly'. Also note that the maximum allowable value for the PatternInterval property is 99.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.PatternMonthOfYear
member.summary: Gets/sets the month of the year on which individual occurrences will occur.

remarks.p: Note: The PatternMonthOfYear property is only applicable when the property is set to 'Yearly'.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.PatternOccurrenceOfDayInMonth
member.summary: Gets/sets whether the recurrence should occur on the first, second, third, fourth or last occurrence of the day of the week (corresponding to the value of the property) in its respective month.

remarks.p: Note: The PatternOccurrenceOfDayInMonth property is only applicable when the property is set to 'Monthly' or 'Yearly'.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.PatternType
member.summary: Gets/sets whether the recurrence pattern is based on a specific day of the month and/or month of the year, or if it is calculated based on other criteria.

remarks.p: Note: The PatternType property is only applicable when the property is set to 'Monthly' or 'Yearly'.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.RangeEndDate
member.summary: Gets/sets the date that defines the end of the recurrence. Applicable only when the property is set to 'LimitByDate'.

remarks.p: Note: When is set to 'NoLimit' or 'LimitByNumberOfOccurrences', setting the RangeEndDate property has no effect; the return value will be calculated, using the recurrence's pattern criteria, for the number of occurrences specified by the property.
The last occurrence of the recurrence does not necessarily coincide with the RangeEndDate, but will never occur later than this date.
Setting the RangeEndDate property to a value that is outside the range determined by the associated ScheduleInfo's and properties will cause an exception to be thrown.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.RangeLimit
member.summary: Gets/sets the limiting factor of the recurrence, i.e., whether it never ends, ends after a certain number of occurrences, or ends on or before a certain date.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.RangeMaxOccurrences
member.summary: Gets/sets the maximum number of occurrences for the recurrence.

remarks.p: Note: The RangeMaxOccurrences property is applicable only when the property is set to 'LimitByNumberOfOccurrences'. Also note that the maximum allowable value for the RangeMaxOccurrences property is 999.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.RangeStartDate
member.summary: Gets/sets the date that defines the beginning of the recurrence.

remarks.p: Note: The first occurrence of the recurrence does not necessarily coincide with the RangeStartDate, but will never occur earlier than this date.
Setting the RangeStartDate property to a value that is outside the range determined by the associated ScheduleInfo's and properties will cause an exception to be thrown.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.RootActivity
member.summary: Returns the object that fully describes all occurrences (except for the date and start/end time) of 'non-variance' recurrences. This acts as a template that describes the subject, location, etc. of the recurrence.

remarks.p: The object referenced by the RootAppointment belongs to the collection. The property of an object that is a root appointment returns an instance of an object whereas all other types of s return null.

Note: Setting the or properties of an object that is assigned to an 's RootAppointment property will cause an exception to be thrown. To modify the starting time of an , set the property. To modify the duration of an , set the property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Recurrence.Variances
member.summary: Returns a collection of s that belong to the recurrence represented by this that have been modified.

remarks.p: Note: The Variances collection's property returns zero if the has not yet been assigned to an .

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Resource.HeaderStyle
member.summary: Returns or sets the object that controls formatting for the 's header.

remarks.p: The Appearance property of an object is used to associate the object with an Appearance object that will determine its appearance. The Appearance object has properties that control settings such as color, borders, font, transparency, etc. For many of the objects in the UltraSchedule, you do not set formatting properties directly. Instead, you set the properties of an Appearance object, which controls the formatting of the object it is attached to.

There are two ways of working with the Appearance property and assigning the attributes of an SSAppearance object to other objects. One way is to create a new Appearance object, adding it directly to the Appearances collection. Then you assign the new Appearance object to the Appearance property of the object you want to format. This method uses a "named" Appearance object that you must explicitly create (and to which you must assign property settings) before it can be used. For instance, you could create an object in the component's Appearances collection and assign it some values as follows:
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances.Add "New1"
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1").BorderColor = Color.Blue
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1").ForeColor = Color.Red

Creating the object in this way does not apply formatting to any visible part of the control. The object simply exists in the collection with its property values, waiting to be used. To actually use the object, you must assign it to the control's (or another object's) Appearance property:
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearance = UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1")

In this case, only one Appearance object exists. The control's appearance is governed by the settings of the "New1" object in the collection. Any changes you make to the object in the collection will immediately be reflected in the control.
The second way of working with the Appearance property is to use it to set property values directly, such as:
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearance.ForeColor = Color.Blue

In this case, an Appearance object is automatically created by the control. This Appearance object is not a member of an Appearances collection and it does not have a name. It is specific to the object for which it was created; it is an "intrinsic" Appearance object. Changes to the properties of an intrinsic Appearance object are reflected only in the object to which it is attached.
Note that you can assign properties from a named Appearance object to an intrinsic Appearance object without creating a dependency relationship. For example, the following code...
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearance.ForeColor = UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1").ForeColor

...does not establish a relationship between the foreground color of the intrinsic object and that of the named object. It is simply a one-time assignment of the named object's value to that of the intrinsic object. In this case, two Appearance objects exist - one in the collection and one attached to the control - and they operate independently of one another.

If you wish to assign all the properties of a named object to an intrinsic object at once without creating a dependency relationship, you can use the Clone method of the Appearance object to duplicate its settings and apply them. So if you wanted to apply all the property settings of the named Appearance object "New1" to the control's intrinsic Appearance object, but you did not want changes made to "New1" automatically reflected in the control, you would use the following code:
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearance = UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1").Clone

Note that the properties of an Appearance object can also operate in a hierarchical fashion. Certain properties can be set to a "use default" value, which indicates to the control that the property should take its setting from the object's parent. This functionality is enabled by default, so that unless you specify otherwise, child objects resemble their parents, and formatting set at higher levels of the control hierarchy is inherited by objects lower in the hierarchy.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.Resource.HasHeaderStyle
member.summary: Indicates whether an object has been created.
member.value: Returns true when the Appearance object for the property has been created.

remarks.p: Use this property to determine if an object has been created. Appearance objects in general are not created until the properties associated with them are accessed.

member.summary: Returns or sets the object that controls selected time slot appearance for this owner in the control.

remarks.p: The Appearance property of an object is used to associate the object with an Appearance object that will determine its appearance. The Appearance object has properties that control settings such as color, borders, font, transparency, etc. For many of the objects in the UltraSchedule, you do not set formatting properties directly. Instead, you set the properties of an Appearance object, which controls the formatting of the object it is attached to.

There are two ways of working with the Appearance property and assigning the attributes of an SSAppearance object to other objects. One way is to create a new Appearance object, adding it directly to the Appearances collection. Then you assign the new Appearance object to the Appearance property of the object you want to format. This method uses a "named" Appearance object that you must explicitly create (and to which you must assign property settings) before it can be used. For instance, you could create an object in the component's Appearances collection and assign it some values as follows:
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances.Add "New1"
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1").BorderColor = Color.Blue
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1").ForeColor = Color.Red

Creating the object in this way does not apply formatting to any visible part of the control. The object simply exists in the collection with its property values, waiting to be used. To actually use the object, you must assign it to the control's (or another object's) Appearance property:
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearance = UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1")

In this case, only one Appearance object exists. The control's appearance is governed by the settings of the "New1" object in the collection. Any changes you make to the object in the collection will immediately be reflected in the control.
The second way of working with the Appearance property is to use it to set property values directly, such as:
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearance.ForeColor = Color.Blue

In this case, an Appearance object is automatically created by the control. This Appearance object is not a member of an Appearances collection and it does not have a name. It is specific to the object for which it was created; it is an "intrinsic" Appearance object. Changes to the properties of an intrinsic Appearance object are reflected only in the object to which it is attached.
Note that you can assign properties from a named Appearance object to an intrinsic Appearance object without creating a dependency relationship. For example, the following code...
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearance.ForeColor = UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1").ForeColor

...does not establish a relationship between the foreground color of the intrinsic object and that of the named object. It is simply a one-time assignment of the named object's value to that of the intrinsic object. In this case, two Appearance objects exist - one in the collection and one attached to the control - and they operate independently of one another.

If you wish to assign all the properties of a named object to an intrinsic object at once without creating a dependency relationship, you can use the Clone method of the Appearance object to duplicate its settings and apply them. So if you wanted to apply all the property settings of the named Appearance object "New1" to the control's intrinsic Appearance object, but you did not want changes made to "New1" automatically reflected in the control, you would use the following code:
UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearance = UltraMonthViewSingle1.Appearances("New1").Clone

Note that the properties of an Appearance object can also operate in a hierarchical fashion. Certain properties can be set to a "use default" value, which indicates to the control that the property should take its setting from the object's parent. This functionality is enabled by default, so that unless you specify otherwise, child objects resemble their parents, and formatting set at higher levels of the control hierarchy is inherited by objects lower in the hierarchy.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.ScheduleMatrix
member.summary: This class controls the means by which appointments are dispersed into AppointmentSubsetCollections suitable for rendering. The class utilizes a an ArrayList of Resources called resourceMatrices. Each ResourceMatrice consists of an Array that contains one entry for each calendar day within the current FrameInterval. Each ResourceMatrice entry is then populated with whatever Appointment objects are relevant to the date represented by the slot. The FrameInterval represents the span of calendar dates that are currently relevant to what WebSchedule is displaying within the user interface. The FrameInterval is normally controlled by the UI elements hooked up to WebScheduleInfo, although the FrameInterval may also be extended by the application.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebScheduleInfo
member.summary: Manages and exposes all date-related data to WebSchedule controls.

remarks.p: The WebScheduleInfo component centralizes all the date specific state information into a single component that can be referenced from all the UltraSchedule controls (). This allows the controls to share the same information across all the controls without the need to maintain the same information on each control.
Use the and properties to change the minimum and maximum dates that the controls can use.
The property maintains the active day and affects each control which is attached to the instance of the WebScheduleInfo.
The and properties are used to determine when a week begins and also how to calculate the week numbers for a particular year.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebScheduleInfo.GetWeekNumberForDate(Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.SmartDate)
member.summary: Returns the week number for a particular date using the current and .
member.param: SmartDate
member.returns: Integer denoting the week number that the date belongs to.

remarks.p: The System.Globalization.Calendar's GetWeekOfYear method simply returns the number of weeks into the year that the date falls on. It does not seem to use the weekrule specified in the arguments. e.g. If the first day of week is sunday and the weekrule is Jan 1, then 12/31/2000 (Sunday) should return 1. Instead it returns 54 and 1/1/2001 (Monday) returns 1.
This routine returns the correct week number for the specified date based on the and .

Note, this may be a week for a year other than the year of the date. e.g. 12/31/2000, week rule of Jan 1, and week start of sunday will return 1 because this date falls into the first week of the year 2001.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebScheduleInfo.FirstDayOfWeekResolved
member.summary: Returns the day of the week considered the start of the week.

remarks.p: By default, the property is set to Default. When left set to this, the considered the first day of the week is based on the system settings of the system using the component.

The and FirstDayOfWeekResolved are used to calculate the date which starts the first week of the year. As such, a object is not fixed to a particular range of dates but is instead associated with a range of dates based on the calculated first week of the year. For more information on how the date of the first week of the year is calculated, refer to the method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebScheduleInfo.LoggedOnUserName
member.summary: Returns a string value representing the current logged on user for WebSchedule. WebScheduleInfo does not use this property for any purpose other than comparing it to the ActiveResourceName. If the two properties are equal, then Reminder events are fired when Activities become current and expire. Otherwise, these events are suppressed when the LoggOnUserName is not the same as the ActiveResourceName. To override this behavior, and application can handle the DataBinding event and set the EnableReminders and/or the EnableActivityActions properties to true.

member.param: Command information passed from the call the client-side script makes through fireServerEvent. This text has no relationship to the similarly-named System.EventArgs class.

remarks.p: This method gets invoked by the framework and is responsible for handling server-side events. Inheritors should not override this method to intercept server-side events before they are handled by the base class. Undefined behavior may result from interference in the event processing of the framework.
Consequently, developers that want to receive notification of an event should subscribe an event handler to the server-side events formally exposed by WebWeekView.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebWeekView.OnPreRender(System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Performs pre-render processing.
member.param: Event arguments passed-in by the ASP.NET Framework during the PreRender stage of the page lifecycle.

remarks.p: Inheritors overriding this method must call the base class implementation. Failure to call the base implementation can lead to Javascript errors resulting from omitting <include> blocks, a loss of styling from the element, and other undesirable behavior.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebWeekView.RenderContents(System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter)
member.summary: Renders contents to the supplied HtmlTextWriter.
member.param: An HtmlTextWriter sink to which output is being directed.

remarks.p: The contents associated with the WebMonthView and rendered by this method include fields to hold postback data from the client, and initialization Javascript to start-up the WebMonthView's client-side object model (CSOM) following the HTML markup comprising the element. RenderContents delegates responsibility for rendering HTML markup to the associated SmartRenderer created by .
Inheritors overriding this method must remember to call the base class implementation of the method before conducting most additional processing.

Post-processing of the rendered content can be accomplished if inheritors intercept what gets written to writer. This involves passing their own HtmlTextWriter wrapping some sort of buffered output sink, for example a StringWriter. When intercepting rendered content in this manner, it becomes the responsibility of the overriding method to ensure necessary content gets forwarded to the original HtmlTextWriter supplied by ASP.NET.
